meta.title: THE LITTLE MATCH GIRL
meta.subtitle: A Vision of Hope in the Cold

slides.title: MODERN REALITY
slides.content:
• Observe: What are the living conditions like?
  • Identify: What is the main 'Complication' for these people?
  • Connect: How would YOU feel in this situation?
slides.notes: Show the first 48 seconds. Elicit immediate reactions. Connect to the concept of 'Complication'.

slides.title: Today's Mission
slides.main_text: We are upgrading your reading skills.
slides.notes: Student-centered objective. Set the stage for success. Emphasize that 'Proof' is the key today.

slides.title: THE STORY SYMBOLS
slides.content:
In pairs, guess how these three items are related in a story set 180 years ago:

  1. A Matchbox
  2. A Roast Goose
  3. A Falling Star
slides.notes: Encourage creative guesses. Write predictions on the board to check later.

slides.title: VICTORIAN DENMARK
slides.content:
Situation: New Year's Eve, 1845.

Is the problem in the modern video similar or different to life 180 years ago?
slides.notes: Establish the historical setting. Elicit that while technology changes, the human experience of cold and poverty remains similar.

slides.title: VOCAB STRATEGY
slides.content:
üó£Ô∏è Guessing from Context

Don't reach for a dictionary! Look at the words around the target word to find clues about its meaning.
slides.notes: Internalize the strategy before seeing the words.

slides.context_sentence: He forgot his shoes at the beach, so he had to walk barefoot on the hot sand.
The boy was shivering because he was standing in the cold rain without a coat.
The magician waved his hand and the rabbit vanished; it was completely gone!
The king lived in a magnificent palace with golden walls and hundreds of rooms.
Many people believe that when the body dies, the soul continues to live forever.

slides.title: MISSION STRATEGY
slides.content:
üîç The Proof Strategy
  • Scan first to find the paragraph.
  • Underline the specific sentence that gives the answer.
  • Explain WHY you chose it.
slides.notes: This is a skills-based lesson (Shape E). The focus is on the process of finding evidence.

slides.title: TASK 1: GIST
slides.content:
Part 1 Context: Skim the B1 text quickly.

Choose the best title for the whole story. Why?

slides.title: TASK 2: THE DETAILS
slides.content:
Answer the 7 Multiple Choice questions on your worksheet.

‚ö†Ô∏è Requirement: You MUST underline the evidence in the text for every answer.
slides.notes: T monitors and ensures evidence is being physically underlined on the paper.

slides.title: ANSWER Q1
slides.explanation:
'She was afraid to go home because her father would be angry...'

Why? The text explicitly states her fear of his anger.
slides.notes: Refer to the anchor text in the JSON.

slides.title: ANSWER Q2
slides.explanation:
'Her hands felt completely frozen.'

Why? Extreme cold leads to loss of feeling.

slides.title: KEYWORD FOCUS
slides.content:
üëÄ Similes & Visions
  • The text says: 'It seemed as if...'
  • This means it is NOT real.
  • She is hallucinating (imagining) it because of the cold.
slides.notes: Concept Check: Was the stove real? (No). How do we know?

slides.title: ANSWER Q3
slides.explanation:
'It seemed to her as if she were sitting in front of a warm iron stove...'

Why? The stove represents warmth and security.
slides.notes: Discuss symbolism: The stove is what she DESIRES.

slides.title: ANSWER Q4
slides.explanation:
'...a falling star meant a soul was going to heaven.'

Why? Her beliefs are based on her grandmother's teachings.

slides.title: ANSWER Q5
slides.explanation:
'She quickly lit the rest of her matches to keep the vision alive.'

Why? Desperation to prevent the grandmother from vanishing.
slides.notes: Ask Ss: Would you do the same?

slides.title: CRITICAL THINKING
slides.content:
ü§î Appearance vs. Reality
  • The Crowd Sees: A dead girl. Sadness.
  • The Girl Sees: Her grandmother. Joy.
  • This contrast is called Dramatic Irony.
slides.notes: Explain that we know something the townspeople don't.

slides.title: ANSWER Q6
slides.explanation:
'No one knew the beautiful things she had seen...'

Why? Her external state (death) contrasts with her internal joy.
slides.notes: Discuss the IRONY. The townspeople are sad, but she experienced 'magnificent splendors'.

slides.title: THE BIG QUESTION
slides.content:
Should we help the poor? Or should they just take care of themselves?

  • Who is responsible for the little girl?
  • What could have been different?
slides.notes: Final personalization stage. Connect back to the modern video.
